revision.comment: The building is 28 Liberty St., as noted in the article. 28 Liberty PLAZA is the public plaza adjacent to the building, not the building itself.
revision.text:
{{Infobox building |name = 28 Liberty Street |status = Complete |image = One Chase Manhattan Plaza 1.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = 28 Liberty Street facade |location = 28 Liberty Street, New York, NY 10005, United States |coordinates = {{coord|40|42|28|N|74|00|32|W|region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} |start_date = January 1957 |completion_date = {{unbulleted list|1961 (Tower)|May 7, 1964 (Plaza)}} |architect = [[Skidmore, Owings and Merrill]] |owner = [[Fosun International]] |floor_area = {{convert|2,299,979|ft2|m2|abbr=on}} |floor_count = 60 (+5 below ground) | map_type = Lower Manhattan#Manhattan#New York City#New York |architectural = {{convert|813|ft|m|abbr=on}} |elevator_count = 37 |structural_engineer= [[Skidmore, Owings and Merrill]], Weiskopf & Pickworth LLP |main_contractor = [[Turner Construction]] | topped_out_date = September 1959 }} '''28 Liberty Street''',<ref>Morris, Keiko, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-landmark-office-tower-in-lower-manhattan-reimagined-1426122301 "A Landmark Office Tower in Lower Manhattan Reimagined" (subscription)], ''Wall Street Journal'', March 11, 2015.</ref> formerly known as '''One Chase Manhattan Plaza''', is a banking [[skyscraper]] located in the downtown Manhattan [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] of [[New York City]], between Pine, Liberty, Nassau, and William Streets. Construction on the building was completed in 1961.<ref>[http://www.som.com/projects/chase_manhattan_bank_tower_and_plaza SOM.com], Completion date</ref> It has 60 floors, with 5 basement floors, and is 248 meters (813 ft) tall, making it the [[List of tallest buildings in New York City|26th tallest building in New York City]], the [[List of tallest buildings in the United States|43rd tallest in the United States]], and the 200th tallest building in the world.<ref>[http://www.emporis.com Emporis.com], Design Specs</ref>
==History== The [[Chase Manhattan Bank]] president of that time, [[David Rockefeller]], the late patriarch of the [[Rockefeller family]], was the prime mover of the construction and the building's location, notably because many corporations had moved uptown, and the Financial District had languished as a result. It was begun in 1956 and completed in 1961.<ref name=WSJ>Morris, Keiko, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/downtown-tower-gets-a-symbolic-new-name-1421026854 "Downtown Tower Gets a Symbolic New Name" (subscription)], ''Wall Street Journal'', January 11, 2015. Retrieved 2017-03-20.</ref>
One Chase Manhattan Plaza is shaped like "an enormous steel-framed rectangle". The {{convert|813|ft|m|abbr=on}} building has about {{convert|1800000|sqft|m2}} of aboveground floor area. Another {{convert|600,000|ft2|m2}} in the basements contains "a truck entrance, mechanical equipment rooms, vaults, a [[[Chase (bank)|Chase]]] branch bank, and a cafeteria". There are [[aluminum]] panels—chosen for their durability and performance—as well as [[mullions]] and [[Column (architecture)|column]] cladding on the facade. The columns are about {{convert|3|by|5|ft|m}} thick and are about {{convert|29|ft|m}} apart from each other. The columns extend from the building on its long sides. The floors [[cantilever]] on the columns on the building's short sides.<ref name=greatbuildings.com>[[Carole Herselle Krinsky|Krinsky, Carole Herselle]], ''[http://www.greatbuildings.com/buildings/Chase_Manhattan_Bank.html Gordon Bunshaft of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]'' (New York: The Architectural History Foundation, 1988) excerpt (pp. 72-74, 76) at ''greatbuildings.com''.</ref>
The New York Landmarks Preservation Commission designated One Chase Manhattan Plaza a landmark in 2008.<ref>[http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/ChaseManhattanReport.pdf "One Chase Manhattan Plaza (aka 16-48 Liberty Street, 26-40 Nassau Street, 28-44 Pine Street, 55-77 William Street)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304204916/http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/ChaseManhattanReport.pdf |date=2016-03-04 }}, Landmarks Preservation Commission, February 10, 2009.</ref> On October 18, 2013, JPMorgan sold the building to Fosun, a [[China|Chinese]] investment company, for $725 million.<ref>{{cite web|last=Levitt |first=David M. |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-10-18/jpmorgan-selling-chase-manhattan-plaza-in-nyc-to-china-s-fosun.html |title=JPMorgan Sells Chase Manhattan Plaza in NYC to China’s Fosun |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2013-10-18 |accessdate=2013-11-27}}</ref> Fosun rebranded One Chase Manhattan Plaza as '''28 Liberty Street''' in 2015.<ref>Bindelglass, Evan, [http://www.yimbynews.com/2015/05/landmarks-wants-re-think-of-re-development-at-28-liberty-street.html "Landmarks Wants Re-Think of Re-Development At 28 Liberty Street"], ''New York YIMBY'', May 6, 2015.</ref>
The new name refers to the east-west street on which the building sits but also connects to the Statue of Liberty in the distance and to "the good fortune that, according to Chinese tradition, is bound up in the number 8 [and] 28 denotes 'double prosperity'".<ref name=WSJ/>
==See also== *[[List of tallest buildings in New York City]]
==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}}
'''Further reading''' * {{cite book|last=Wilson|first=John D.|title=The Chase: The Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A., 1945-1985|year=1986|publisher=Harvard Business School Press|location=Boston, Mass|isbn=978-0-87584-134-2}}
==External links== {{commons category|One Chase Manhattan Plaza}} *[http://www.som.com/content.cfm/one_chase_manhattan_plaza One Chase Manhattan Plaza] on [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill|SOM]] website *[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/19/nyregion/thecity/19landmark.html?scp=2&sq=manhattan+plaza&st=nyt New York Times: A Landmark From the Start, Now Getting Its Official Due ]

revision.comment: [[WP:CHECKWIKI]] error fix for #61. Punctuation goes before References. Do [[Wikipedia:GENFIXES|general fixes]] if a problem exists. -
revision.text:
[[File:Acid Egg Catalyst 2011.jpg|thumb|right|Acid Egg on display at the Catalyst Museum, 2011]] The terms '''acid egg''' and '''montejus''' (or '''monte-jus''') are sometimes used interchangeably to refer to a device with no moving parts formerly used instead of a pump in order to transfer difficult liquids.<ref name=Schaschke>Carl Schaschke (2014) ''Dictionary of Chemical Engineering'' (Oxford University Press) p 245</ref><ref name=Killeffer>D. H. Killeffer (1924) ''Industrial and Engineering Chemistry'' Vol. 16, No. 8 pp 785–8 “Tools of the Chemical Engineer”</ref> The principle is that a strong vessel containing the liquid is pressurized with gas or steam, forcing the liquid into a pipe (usually vertical upwards) thereby causing flow. When the liquid has been transferred, the pressure is released and more liquid is put in via gravity. It is thus cyclic in operation. The same principle has been used to lift water and called an ''air displacement pump'' or ''intermittent gas-lift pump'', and has been applied to pumping oil up from the formation.<ref name=Shell>R. J. Forbes & D. R. O'Beirne (1957) ''The Technical Development of the Royal Dutch/Shell: 1890-1940'' p233</ref> Its use has largely been superseded by modern pumps, but it is still used sometimes for special tasks.
==Acid Egg== This was specifically devised to deal with the highly corrosive [[sulfuric acid]], but was extended to other corrosive substances. It was traditionally made of ceramic (to be corrosion resistant) and spherical in shape (to withstand the pressure) thus giving its name.<ref name=MW>''Miriam-Webster Dictionary''</ref> A cylindrical version (with hemispherical ends) was described by Swindin, being 3 feet in diameter and 6 feet long, holding 40 cubic feet of acid.<ref name=Swindin>Swindin, N., (1922) ''Pumps in Chemical Engineering'' (Benn, London) pp 48–9</ref> In principle, the vessel is part filled with liquid, which is then expelled by pumping in compressed air. The liquid outlet is via a pipe from the top going down almost to the bottom of the vessel. When the acid egg is emptied, connections to the compressor and the delivery pipe are closed by valves, the air pressure is vented and the vessel refilled with acid. The cycle can then start again.<ref name=Swindin/>
==Montejus== A French invention used in [[Sugar#Production|sugar production]] to move the partially processed sugar liquid up a pipe to the next stage of purification. Hence the name “monte-jus” or “raise juice”. Unlike the acid egg, it traditionally consists of a vertical cylindrical vessel made of steel, with a pipe from the bottom turned upwards, and it is pressurized by steam.<ref name=SciAm1868Ap24>[[Scientific American]], April 24, 1869 pp 261–2, “Beet Root Sugar part V”</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Pumps]] [[Category:Chemical equipment]] [[Category:Chemical industry]] [[Category:History of sugar]]

page.title: Albert, 12th Prince of Thurn and Taxis

revision.text:
{{Infobox royalty |name = Albert |title = Prince of Thurn and Taxis |full name = {{lang-de|Albert Maria Lamoral Miguel Johannes Gabriel Prinz von Thurn und Taxis}} |image = Albert TT 2011.jpg |caption = Prince Albert in 2011 |reign = {{nowrap|14 December 1990 – present}} |reign-type = Period |predecessor = [[Johannes, 11th Prince of Thurn and Taxis|Johannes]] |successor = [[Prince Max Emanuel of Thurn and Taxis (b. 1935)|Prince Max Emanuel]] |suc-type = [[Heir presumptive]] |succession = [[Thurn and Taxis|Head of the House of Thurn and Taxis]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1983|06|24}} |birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Regensburg]], [[Bavaria]], Germany}} |religion = [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] |father = [[Johannes, 11th Prince of Thurn and Taxis]] |mother = [[Gloria, Princess of Thurn and Taxis|Countess Gloria of Schönburg-Glauchau]] | house = [[House of Thurn and Taxis|Thurn and Taxis]] }} {{Thurn und Taxis}} '''Albert Maria Lamoral Miguel Johannes Gabriel, 12th Prince of Thurn and Taxis''' (Albert Fürst von Thurn und Taxis;In 1919 royalty and nobility were mandated to lose their privileges in Germany, hereditary titles were to be legally borne thereafter only as part of the surname, according to [http://www.zum.de/psm/weimar/weimar_vve.php#First_Chapter_:_The_Individual Article 109] of the [[Weimar Constitution]]. Styles such as ''majesty'' and ''highness'' [http://www.bmi.bund.de/cae/servlet/contentblob/150142/publicationFile/35310/Anschriften.pdf were not retained.] born 24 June 1983), is a German [[aristocracy (class)|aristocrat]], businessman, and race car driver.{{Cite news |title=The 20 Hottest Young Royals - 11. Prince Albert|url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/05/23/royals-celebrity-monarchs-biz-billies-cz_ls_0527royals_slide_12.html |publisher=''[[Forbes]]'' |date=27 May 2008 |accessdate=4 June 2008}}Willis, Daniel. The Descendants of Louis XIII. Clearfield, 1999, Baltimore, US. {{ISBN|0-8063-4942-5}}.{{rp|540}}{{cite book | title=Genealogisches Handbuch des Adels: Furstliche Hauser Band XIX | publisher=C. A. Starke Verlag | year=2011 | location=Limburg an der Lahn | pages=369, 382–383, 385–386 | isbn=978-3-7980-0849-6}} He has been listed as the world's youngest billionaire many times since his father's death in 1990,{{Cite news |title=The Conversation of Gloria TNT|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2006/06/princesstnt200606 |publisher=''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' |date=June 2006 |accessdate=26 June 2015}} first appearing on the list when he was age eight. ==Biography== ===Family=== The House of [[Thurn und Taxis]] is a German family whose fortune derives from the appointment of an ancestor, Leonhard von Taxis, as hereditary [[postmaster general]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] in 1595. Albert's father preceded him as the [[House of Thurn and Taxis line of succession|head of this family]], which has several branches. The family of Thurn und Taxis remains well known as owners of brewerieshttps://www.thurnundtaxisbiere.de and former builders of castles. His father, [[Johannes, 11th Prince of Thurn and Taxis]]{{Cite news |title=Johannes Erbprinz von Thurn und Taxis, By Academy of Achievement|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/podcast/johannes-erbprinz-von-thurn-und-taxis/id439163091?mt=2 |publisher=''iTunes Preview'' |date=2011 |accessdate=18 October 2018}}, an internationally renowned [[Flâneur|''boulevardier'']], died in 1990 when he was seven years old, leaving Albert to inherit a US$3 billion fortune and US$500 million in debts. His mother, [[Gloria, Princess of Thurn and Taxis|Gloria]] (''née'' Countess von [[House of Schönburg#Counts of Schönburg-Glauchau (1700)|Schönburg-Glauchau]]), a popular media figure since marriage to his 53-year-old father as a 20-year-old, was instrumental in preserving the family fortune until Albert became of legal age to take over its management. He has two older sisters: [[Princess Maria Theresia of Thurn and Taxis (b. 1980)|Princess Maria Theresia]] and [[Elisabeth von Thurn und Taxis|Princess Elisabeth]]. ===Education=== Thurn und Taxis completed his high school education in Rome and then, after his military service, he studied economics and theology at the [[University of Edinburgh]]. ===Media attention=== [[File:Albert Thurn Und Taxis 20080629 Norisring 660x990.jpg|thumb|Prince Albert in 2008]] In 2008 Albert was included as 11th on the list of the Forbes Magazine's List of The 20 Hottest Young Royals as compiled by ''[[Forbes Magazine|Forbes]]'' magazine. ===Motorsport=== He is an enthusiastic racing driver, vice-champion (2007/2008) and champion (2010) of the German GT Championship [[ADAC GT Masters]] with the German Team [[Reiter Engineering]].https://www.adac-gt-masters.de/uk/fahrerportrait-2011/albert-von-thurn-und-taxis-1635/ He embarked on a career in rallying in 2009, competing in the [[European Rally Championship]] since 2016.https://www.ewrc-results.com/profile/12891-albert-von-thurn-und-taxis/ ==Titles, styles and honours== Since former hereditary titles are only recognised in [[German law]] as part of the surname, in accordance with the [[Weimar Constitution]] of 1919, family members include the title as an integral part of their name in the form, ''Prinz von Thurn und Taxis''. According to family tradition Albert Prinz von Thurn und Taxis followed his father, in accordance with the rules of the legal affairs committee of the Association of German Nobility (''[[:de:Deutscher Adelsrechtsausschuß|Deutscher Adelsrechtsausschuß]]''), in the nominal succession as "head" of the former German princely House of [[Thurn and Taxis]]. As such, he is sometimes styled by the traditional title, ''[[Fürst]] von Thurn und Taxis'' (Prince of Thurn and Taxis). ===Titles and styles=== Traditional: * '''28 June 1983{{spaced ndash}} 14 December 1990''': ''His Serene Highness'' Prince Albert of Thurn and Taxis * '''14 December 1990{{spaced ndash}} present''': ''His Serene Highness'' Albert, the Prince of Thurn and Taxis ===Dynastic honours=== Honours of non-reigning families * [[Thurn und Taxis|House of Thurn und Taxis]]: Grand Master Knight Grand Cross of the [[Order of Parfaite Amitié]]{{cite web|url=https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/2f/22/7e/2f227e96d4b49b1566abf6deb647f4c2.jpg |format=JPG |title=Photographic image |website=S-media-cache-ak0.pinig.com |accessdate=2016-11-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.altrofoto.de/index.php/Taxis+Portrait+Portr%E4t+%28von+links%29+Beatrice+Gr%E4fin+von+Sch%F6nburg-Glauchau+Alexander/layout-146808.html |title=altro - die fotoagentur : 01468-08 |website=Altrofoto.de |date= |accessdate=2016-11-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.altrofoto.de/index.php/Taxis+Portrait+Portr%E4t+F%FCrst+Albert+von+Thurn+und+Taxis+Festakt/layout-144608.html |title=altro - die fotoagentur : 01446-08 |website=Altrofoto.de |date= |accessdate=2016-11-13}} * [[House of Bourbon-Two Sicilies|Calabrian House of Bourbon-Two Sicilies]]: Knight Grand Cross of Justice of the [[Sacred Military Constantinian Order of Saint George|Calabrian Two Sicilian Order of Saint George]]{{cite web|url=https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/236x/b7/2a/fa/b72afa097230a4f1b46ad71269a3077e.jpg |format=JPG |title=Photographic image |website=S-media-cache-ak0.pinig.com |accessdate=2016-11-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.constantinianorder.org/news/archive-2008/09-10-2008-london-mass-and-investiture-at-the-.html |title=09/10/2008 (London) Mass and Investiture at the |website=Constantinianorder.org |date=2008-10-09 |accessdate=2016-11-13}} ==Ancestry== Through descent from king [[Miguel I of Portugal]] he is related to several reigning hereditary heads of state in Europe. He also descends from the dynasties of [[Wittelsbach]], [[House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha|Saxe-Coburg-Gotha]], [[House of Braganza|Braganza]] and the [[House of Habsburg-Lorraine]].{{rp|536–540, 778}} {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. revision.comment: Added an example of a spoof paper accepted.
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = BIT Life Sciences | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | former_name = | type = | industry = Scientific meetings | founded = 2003 <!-- if known: {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} in [[city]], [[country]] --> | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | hq_location = | hq_location_city = [[Dalian Hi-Tech Zone]] | hq_location_country = [[China]] | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = | brands = | services = | owner = Xiaodan Mei | homepage = {{URL|www.bitlifesciences.com/}} }} '''BIT Life Sciences''' (or '''BIT Congress''' Inc., '''BIT Group Global''' Ltd) is a [[Predatory open access publishing|predatory]], for profit [[Meetings, incentives, conferencing, exhibitions|meetings, incentives, conferencing, exhibitions (MICE)]] company based in Dalian, China<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/company-profile.BIT_Congress_Inc.09f0f9c8c47a7f59.html|title =BIT Congress Inc. Company Information|accessdate = 20 October 2015|publisher = dnb.com}}</ref> that specializes in arranging multiple [[scientific congress]]es that have been described as "predatory".<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/27593/title/Conference-kerfuffle-hits-scientists|title =Conference kerfuffle hits scientists|accessdate = 7 Feb 2014|publisher = The-scientist.com}}</ref> <ref name="Cohen2013">{{cite journal|last=Cohen|first=John|date=2013-04-10|title=Meetings That Flatter, but May Not Deliver|journal=Science|volume=342|issue=6154|page=76|doi=10.1126/science.342.6154.76}}<!--|accessdate=2015-06-13 --></ref> The company is part of a wave of organizations that have appeared in China in past several years noted for arranging congresses with little academic merit and with the primary aim of generating revenue rather than scientific knowledge sharing.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/08/health/for-scientists-an-exploding-world-of-pseudo-academia.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1&ref=todayspaper&|title =Scientific Articles Accepted (Personal Checks, Too)|accessdate = 7 Feb 2014|publisher = New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.medicalobserver.com.au/news/warning-on-rising-hoax-conference-invites|title =Warning on rising hoax conference invites|accessdate = 7 Feb 2014|publisher = Medical Observer}}</ref> Papers submitted are usually accepted without revisions within 24 hours, and BIT has frequently been spoofed (see this example: http://witchdoctor.ca/?p=892).
== Business model ==
The business model of this company usually involves sending promotional email to invite attendees and speakers, at the same time, registration fee will be provided based on different levels of speakers in relevant fields. Unlike traditional model of scientific congresses in which abstracts are usually submitted and [[peer reviewed]] before being accepted for presentation, speakers are guaranteed a speaking role as long as the attendance fees are paid. <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://pipeline.corante.com/archives/2009/04/28/dear_dr_derek_.php |title=In the pipeline |accessdate=7 Feb 2014 |publisher=Corante |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222015816/http://pipeline.corante.com/archives/2009/04/28/dear_dr_derek_.php |archivedate=2014-02-22 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://scimedskeptic.wordpress.com/tag/fake-scientific-conferences-are-like-genuine-scientific-conferences/|title =Fake scientific conferences are like genuine scientific conferences|accessdate = 7 Feb 2014|publisher = Scimedskeptic}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.lib.umn.edu/denis036/thisweekinevolution/2013/02/more_fake-scientific-conferenc.html |title=More fake scientific conferences |accessdate=7 Feb 2014 |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012144648/http://blog.lib.umn.edu/denis036/thisweekinevolution/2013/02/more_fake-scientific-conferenc.html |archivedate=2013-10-12 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|1}}
[[Category:Companies of China]] [[Category:Companies based in Dalian]] [[Category:Internet marketing companies]] [[Category:Academic conferences]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]]

{{other uses}} {{refimprove|date=October 2015}} [[Image:Warpedtourpass.jpg|thumb|203px|Warped Tour 2006 All Access Pass]] A '''backstage pass''' is an employee pass which allows its bearer access to employees-only areas at a performance venue. They are most commonly associated with [[rock music]] groups.
Such passes are usually a laminated paper worn on a lanyard, or on chain link or key chain holder at the belt, or a simpler "stick-on" applied to one's clothing. Plastic or paper wristbands may also be used. However, some elaborately designed backstage passes have been used by [[Bill Graham (promoter)|Bill Graham]] Productions/Winterland, Beaver Productions and many other regional and local promoters. To deter counterfeiting, passes often include holograms or color-shifting properties.
At any one concert or event there are about 200 to 400 backstage passes available. Again, mainly these are for the performers, stage crews, roadies, security guards, performer's agents. Sometimes relatives or close friends of performers, stage crew, promoters, etc. will get backstage passes to concerts.
Some venues (including the [[House of Blues]] venues and Irving Plaza in New York) require their own passes to be worn, even by laminate holders for the tour. Large music festivals, such as [[Ozzfest]] and the [[Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival]] also usually issue their own passes.
Backstage passes sometimes become [[memorabilia]] sold to die-hard fans, especially when the pass is signed by a performer.
In media, the term "Backstage Pass" may be used to signify the presence of expanded coverage of certain musical groups.
==Types of passes== There are a number of different types of backstage passes:
*All Access passes allow the bearer unlimited access to the performance venue. Such passes are generally restricted to the performers, their crew and management, and management of the venue. *Stage Crew passes are used by those who set up the stage. If used by local, temporary help, such passes are usually valid only during this part of day, and not for during or after the show. *Other employee passes for people who work specific jobs in support of the act, such as catering, security, and merchandising personnel. *Passes for media, such as press reporters and photographers. *Limited Access passes are usually intended for specially selected fans that get to "meet and greet" the performers, and can also be used for guests of the band in order to give them VIP status. Sometimes these passes will actually have VIP printed on them. These passes are often issued for afterparties. *Backstage passes are also given out by the band and band's manager to selected fans who want to hang out with the band. These passes are commonly associated with [[groupies]], and are frequently issued for afterparties.
Otto Printing (in Kentucky) and PERRi Entertainment (in Reno, NV) helped establish the industry and were two of the largest manufactures and designers of passes up until 2003. When PERRi folded, the current leading printer of backstage passes emerged: [http://www.accesseventsolutions.com ACCESS Event Solutions.] Reno has become the largest source for backstage pass printing. Otto is still printing passes and is the oldest printer of backstage passes. While currently Reno and Otto Printing produce the largest amount of back stage passes, there are many companies looking to surpass them in it.<ref>[http://www.idcreator.com/back-stage-passes|date=June 2013]</ref>
There are some ways to get backstage passes. One way is to get employed for the venue. Some backstage passes are given as prizes by official fan clubs. Sometimes local radio stations and/or local music shops will obtain one or a few from the concert promoters or their agents and will give away as a type of promotional prize.
==See also== * [[Ticket (admission)|Ticket]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Backstage Pass}} [[Category:Ephemera]] [[Category:Business documents]]
